greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array read by descending antidiagonals: If n > k, A(n,k) = T(lcm(n,k), gcd(n,k)), otherwise A(n,k) = T(gcd(n,k), lcm(n,k)), where T(n,k) is sequence A000027 considered as a two-dimensional table.
comment: The array is read by descending antidiagonals as A(1,1), A(1,2), A(2,1), A(1,3), A(2,2), A(3,1), etc.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10585; the first 145 antidiagonals of array
formula: If n > k, A(n,k) = T(lcm(n,k),gcd(n,k)), otherwise A(n,k) = T(gcd(n,k),lcm(n,k)), where T(n,k) is sequence A000027 considered as a two-dimensional table, that is, as a pairing function from N x N to N.
If n < k, A(n,k) = A286101(n,k), otherwise A(n,k) = A286102(n,k).
example: The top left 12 X 12 corner of the array:
program: (define (A285724bi row col) (if (> row col) (A000027bi (lcm row col) (gcd row col)) (A000027bi (gcd row col) (lcm row col))))
(define (A000027bi row col) (* (/ 1 2) (+ (expt (+ row col) 2) (- row) (- (* 3 col)) 2)))
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, May 03 2017
